comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content: Who was capturing and who was captured in this photo?

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Excellent shot once again NLI.  As you said they do look relaxed though the future of the prisoner might be rather uncertain.  He is a fine looking young man and there is almost a sense of relief in his expression.  Patrick the men in uniform are Free State or Pro-treaty soldiers and the young prisoner is a Republican rebel or anti-treaty soldier.  Both were probably on the same side some months earlier fighting against the British and now they were killing each other with equal ferocity in their disagreement as to how the war should have ended.  The prisoner is one of the lucky ones because as usual in civil wars mercy was not always shown by either side.

comment._content: looks like a film set. very relaxed!!

comment.author: 46650209@N07
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/swordscookie] Thanks! Civil wars are not a pleasant situation at all!
Speaking about uniforms, leather gaiters were a typical element of the Irish military uniform, right into the "Emergency" WW2 period, replacing puttees.
In other armies leather gaiters were issued only to mounted and motorised troops.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/patrick_castelli] Thanks, Patrick, have tagged for gaiters.

comment.author: 69587809@N05
comment._content:
'Here, give me your rifle,' an English officer said to an Irish soldier in the Civil War after he had seen him missing a rebel several times. 'Indeed, I will not,' the soldier answered indignantly.
'You might kill the poor boy.' This story circulated amongst English officers in Ireland in 1922 and the relationship between army and rebels at the beginning is captured uniquely in the picture from the National Library. 
McMahon, Paul. British Spies and Irish Rebels. 2008. The Boydell Press and Google Books

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/69587809@N05] Thanks for that! Had never heard that story before...
